response.answer_text: “Reason” is a cause, or an explanation, its primary use is to see things logically or for how it really is in an argument: “I’m trying to reason with him, but he just won’t listen.” or “What’s your reason for seeing my daughter at 3 in the morning?”. “Reasoning” is the same word but with the added “ing”, “ing” is a suffix used to describe something that's currently happening, here “reasoning” is used to describe how someone is currently viewing or (usually) logically coming to a conclusion: “His reasoning for believing the earth is round checks out.” The other way to view it is you use a prior example: “I’m reasoning with him right now, he seems to be listening.” Reason and Reasoning are basically the same word, but used a bit differently given the context of a situation.

a) Reason stands as an initiating factor due to which something happened. It is noun. b) Reason also stands for a set of facts presented in support or against something. It is also noun. c) Reasoning is the verb to b) above.
